conclusion: Determine the force exerted by the small ball on the light rod at the highest point P using energy conservation and circular motion dynamics.
The small ball is given an upward velocity v0 = 4 m/s from a horizontal position.
At the highest point P, the ball has both potential and kinetic energy.
Calculate initial kinetic energy: KE_initial = 1/2 * m * v0^2 = 8 J.
Calculate potential energy at the highest point: PE = mgh = 5 J.
Calculate final kinetic energy at point P: KE_final = KE_initial - PE = 3 J.
Determine velocity at point P from kinetic energy: v = sqrt(6) m/s.
At the highest point P, forces acting on the ball are tension in the rod and gravitational force.
Net force provides centripetal force: T + mg = mv^2/L.
Substitute known values to find tension: T + 10 N = 12 N.
Tension acts along the rod towards the center of the circular path, downward at point P.
Final answer: Magnitude of force is 2 N, direction is downward.
